Problem:

Whenever I start the RAC on our linux 390 box I get the following exception:

java.net.BindException: Address already in use
        at java.net.PlainSocketImpl.socketBind(Native Method)
        at java.net.PlainSocketImpl.bind(PlainSocketImpl.java:355)
        at java.net.ServerSocket.bind(ServerSocket.java:340)
        at java.net.ServerSocket.<init>(ServerSocket.java:207)
        at java.net.ServerSocket.<init>(ServerSocket.java:119)
        at
org.eclipse.hyades.internal.execution.file.FileServer.run(FileServer.java)

Note that despite this exception, the RAC seems to work fine.  I can remotely
profile the applications without any problem

This exception is being thrown because, there is probably another instance of 
the RAC file server or some other process listening on the file server port of 
the RAC (10005). The port number to which the file server binds can be 
configured by editing the serviceconfig.xml file. This problem can be fixed by 
changing the file server port to another port which is currently not in use.

In any case, this should provide the user with a more meaningful message and
record the exception in the log file rather than dump it to the command prompt.

This exception needs to be caught and logged as Navid suggests. I have 
targetted it for 3.1 I2.
I talked to Bob about this defect, and retargetted this defect to 3.2

This is in response to Navid's first comment. I implemented a fix for this 
problem, and while I was testing my fix by profiling with 2 instances of RAC 
running simultaneously (on different control ports), I found that if we try to 
connect to the RAC which was started last, we cannot profile the application. 
Though a java process is launched by the RAC, we cannot profile the 
application. (even without my fix)

So Navid has been able to profile successfully even after the FileServer did 
not start, but the control server started a second time, probably because his 
profiling application was connected to the RAC that started first.

Is this a known issue? i.e the user not being able to use the second RAC to 
profile his applications.

This is a known issue.  The results are unpredictable when two instances of the 
RAC are running on the same machine.  That is not a supported scenario.

The fix for this defect has been checked into the Hyades HEAD (3.2) stream. So 
I am closing this defect.

Resolution description:
I now catch IOExceptions and BindExceptions that could occur in the file 
server and set error codes. After the file server is started from the Agent 
Controller, I check for the error status, and if there has been a 
BindException or IOException, I log the error messages, instead of dumping the 
stack trace on the console.
